Each dichotomy card gives one negative and one positive property, e.g. +1 speed, -1 hunger. Players have stats that affected by dichotomy cards. | Icon | Stat | Limit |Description | |-----------------|-------------------------|-------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | ![health](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/health.png) | Heal | 6 | Allows to player endure bad conditions if reaches zero, player dies. | | ![hunger](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/hunger.png) | Hunger | 6 | Decreases one on each step if reaches zero player dies. | | ![strength](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/strength.png) | Strength | 4 | Power of player to handle encounters. Either against card or players. | | ![stamina](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/stamina.png) | Stamina | 4 | Decreases one on each step. If zero player must one turn to gain. | | ![speed](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/icons/speed.png) | Speed | 3 | Determines how many tiles player could move at once. |
Table 1: Player Stats
![Player Movement](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/player_movement.png)
Figure 3: Player Movement
__Tracking player stats__ Each player gets a player card that has slot for cardriges of each stat. As player moves on the dichotomy card, one applies the stat changes on their card by giving/taking color distincted stat cardridges. Player cannot fill more than maximum amount of the stat. Each player should explicitly show their stat cards to other players. ![Player Sheet and Cartridges](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/player_sheet.png)
Figure 4: Player Sheet and Stat Cartridges
__The game can be won in more in various ways__ - By eliminating all the other players - Reaching the safe zone in the middle - By visiting 3 players starting place and acquiring their spawnstones. __Dichotomy Cards__ are step-over decisions that affects player stats. It contains minimum 3 basic information. These are: name of the card, positive aspect, and negative aspect. __Dichotomy Card Levels__ There are three groups of dichotomy cards distinguished by color. These groups are there to prevent players from moving around the map with uniform ease, and to create some alignment rules to prevent randomization from creating cul de sac situations that players lose at the early game. In other words, randomization is intended to introduce the factor of luck into the game, whereas alignment rules are there to prevent chance of being the dominant factor and overriding the player's decisions. | Color | Level | Desciption | |------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Green | Easy | Regular trade-off | | Yellow | Medium | Unfair trade-off | | Orange | Hard | Extremely unfair trade-off | __Step over preventation__ The card the player steps on is flipped over and grayed out. This card loses its effect until the player exits the adjacent cards. At the end of each round the non-adjacent cards are reactivated. In order to win the game, the player needs to create a progressive strategy by balancing their stats on the maps and reading the actions of the other players. ![Dichotomy Card](/nuxt_content/dichotomies/dichotomy_card.png)
Figure 5: Dichotomy card (Back and Front)
__Dichotomy Card Examples__ | Name | Positive Aspect | Negative Aspect | |------------------|--------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | Hunt | +1 Hunger | -1 Stamina | | Stay | +1 Energy | -1 Hunger, No movement | | Training | +1 Strength | -1 Stamina, -1 Hunger | | Teleport | -2 Energy, -1 Speed | Move to desired location | | Portal | -1 Energy, -1 Hunger | Move to designated location (other portal) | | ... | ... | ... | - Variations of dichotomy card is to be added considering the balance to extend the complexity of game. __Player versus Player__ Player could attack and kill other players. To hit another player, target player should be in the attack range by the player. Attacking another player costs 1 hunger and energy equal to players strength. If attacker players energy lesser than his/her strength, then player hit strength is regarded equivalent to as his/her stamina. Hit amount is decreased from attacked player's health. If it the health of attacked player reaches zero. Attacked player dies and attacker takes the position of attacked player, otherwise positions stays same. # Modes and Variations - **Complexity Level 1:** - There are certain single-use items added on the map with some rules. That enhances the stats extensively beyond limits, or provides unique abiltiy - ex. bow, bicycle etc. - **Complexity Level 2:** - Players have a technology tree and materials among map to create items in complexity level 2. - ex. Research cooking, weapon craft - **Immortal mode:** - the killed player reborns on starting zone. Loses his collected spawnstones # Story In a post-apocalyptic world, there is scarce of sources to accommodate all. Survivalists compete against each other against each other to live. # Theory The statement _decisions comes with trade-offs_ holds the subtle message of this game. One of the principles that I have adopted in the late stage of my life as I have learned through experience. I encounter often the falsification about the perception of the concept of decision. As it to be regarded something to gain but at the same time not to lose. A decision, choosing one of the two or more options. It opens up a new path, but it also means that other paths are closed. It might seem about a cruel reality. Yet it bear an austere elegance and beauty because decisions are the mere qualities of character that describes who we are. Accepting the responsibility of two-sided condition of a decision not only make us more mature but progress as a being. As a result, the game aimed to express the statement in an entertaining way. # References and Credits __Visual References__ 1. All figures in the article produced by the author. 2. Icons used in **Table 1** is from _Shikashi's Fantasy Icons Pack_. Images are manipulated by the author. __Used Assets__ 1. _Shikashi's Fantasy Icons Pack_. n.d. Accessed (25-Jan-2023) https://cheekyinkling.itch.io/shikashis-fantasy-icons-pack __Used Sources__ 1. Blender Hand Drawn Shader Tutorial. _Littlerolz - Youtube_ [Video File]. 2019. Accessed (19-Jan-2023) https://youtu.be/YDHGm1W0A-c 2. Hexagon World with Geometry Nodes Fields - Blender 3.0 Tutorial. _Erindale - Youtube_ [Video File]. 2022. Accessed (19-Jan-2023) https://youtu.be/EboNtLKn_m8 __Used Programs__ 1. Adobe Photoshop CC 2. Blender 3.4.1 --- ## Swapfold # Description Swapfold is a single player origami puzzle/storyline-rpg mix top-down platformer game with a unique fundamental feature. Players must replicate actions on real world in order to find some solutions to puzzles. The main idea of the game to establishing a ground to show that games has potential as an environment to be a platform of education. On the completition of the game player should be able to learn few origami pieces through the method of associative learning. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/chapters.png)
Figure 1: Basic level origamis selected for each chapter
# Story Our player is an apprentice mage who has to train portals. His supervisor gives him extraordinary tasks to complete. In order to understand how interdimensionality works you should be able to accurately represent and simulate them in simple dimensions. Idea comes from quartenions. So he/she starts to learn to play with simple tasks. However, during one of his tasks something goes wrong and a portal opens to demonic world of caridia. Now our characters needs to focus on his training to overcome this problem. Story | Draft | Hidden Test not: burayi yeniden yaz story pek iyi degil.
# Base Gameplay Gameplay starts with a simple platformer game with moving around and exploring the world. With a simple mixed combat and puzzle feature for complex spells. Like a cookbook analogy in programming our character learns simple unitary modular folding techniques to create simple origami pieces, each of which associated with a power word, that could be used combine and casts spells ingame. This techniques progresss further on a skill tree. It is aimed that the skill tree also resembles what player learned in real life as well. On each chapter player requires to create an origami piece. Writing a mark on number on each fold. At the end opening crafted origami piece on 2D reveals a map on how to solve a puzzle in game. Each power word is associated with a folding technique. Player uses keyboard shortcuts to cast power words. Spells are usually combination of (usually 3 or 4) few power words. In RPG combat player must cast spells. A complex set of power words represent portals as well as origami pieces. Each power word is learned through a simple puzzle. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/skill_tree.png)
Figure 2: Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree
(hint: try dark mode)
# Mechanics Basic game mechanics is a adjusted combination of two main mechanics. Those are moderate paced, environmentally interactive top-down RPG game play and puzzle solving. __Spell Word Combinations__ Each spell is combination of one or more power words. During RPG combat, player uses the combination of power words through _button combos_ to cast spell to overcome challenges. This combinations further helps player to solve puzzles through replicating origami pieces in real life. Example systems in real games (Ultima Online, Skyrim, Magicka). __Progressive Casting__ Casting a spell requires a small amount of time. Each cast process has three periods. Those are: _fizzle_, _success_, _excession_. With the analogy of cooking, _fizzle_ states represents a failing cast. If player ends casts too early, spell fizzles, simply fails without any effect. After the end of fizzle, _success_ period begins. During success, effect of spell increases exponantially until until excession period. The latest stage of the cast is _excession_ period. _Excession_ state is guaranteed failing cast and harms the player depending on the combination of spells. The harm is maximum at start and decreases parabolically up to half of maximum success effect. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_graph.png)
Figure 3: Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods
On the combinations, different power words affect the cast time and proportions of the cast periods. Along with the mastery and usage frequency of the player. Through the mix of spell word combination and progressive casting, it is aimed to create create precision input button combos, fun to play but hard to master base combat mechanics of the game. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/cast_bar.png)
Figure 4: Periods of Cast Bar
__Real World Replication__ Player requires to solve a puzzle a to unlock, final chapter battles in game. A typical puzzle is again combination of power words, ingredients or keys to be used on certain sequence or places. This sequence is revealed through creating an origami piece through instructions explored in sub-chapters. On each fold player writes a power word on paper in real world. After completing and unfolding the origami piece, map for solving the puzzle is revealed. The sequence of instructions, and words are randomized to create unique map for each instance of the game. __Example Puzzle Chapter__ - Game consist of chapters each chapters corresponds an origami piece, and chapters consists of sub-chapters each of one corresponds to fold-technique. - During sub-chapter with different hints player learns origami by retrieving knowledge such as which fold-technique to be used, how many times and where. Player could replicate this information step to create origami piece. - On certain steps, player are given some additional power words (as runes) for portal keys. On this case, the given rune needs to be written on indicated area before applying the fold. - Completing the chapter, will result to complete the origami as well. However, to unlock next chapter, player requires to handle a boss fight. The boss fight room always resembles the unfolded paper of origami piece. On certain periods, boss stops and an area is indicated by color or light. On this time player should go to given area and cast the passing power word in given time. - If player had replicated given fold techniques in real life, unfolding the origami should reveal the true power words, in that player could use true power word to cast the portal. - Upon completing successful RPG boss fight with the combination of origami puzzle player defeats the boss and gains access to the new chapter. Along with learning an origami in real life. ![Player Placement](/nuxt_content/swapfold/mapping.png)
Figure 5: Puzzle Solving Steps Depiction
__Puzzle Generation Steps__ 1. Description selected origami for the chapter as a composition of folding steps. 2. Decision on which steps to write a power rune on fold. 3. Writing of appropriate questline for each fold and rune to reveal map. 4. Design of boss fight mechanics and space that bears resemblance of unfolded origami. # Theory __Environmental Interactions__ As a general principle, it is aimed to increase the interaction with the environment for player. Environment is not only frozen entity to move and orient for next encounter but also, something to be aware of and act depending of the requirements of the place. Player should be able to change, alter or impact on the environment. At the same time strategicaly use it for personal progression. Example cases: - Frost based spells has multipliers to hit greater to wet enemies. - Player should avoid using fire spells on environment with dry woods to create fire. - Player should position themselves tactically to avoid impact boulder rolls, and even use this phenomenon to encounter with enemies. __Integrated Mini Games__ One of the problems that I have encountered in online games, that crafted objects costs lesser than material itself. Which is often wrong compared to the real world. The problem is gathering costs labor, however crafting does not, as a result since the material has variety of usage it worth more. To compete with this problem. It is aimed to set alternative progression mechanics such as crafting to be supported by engraved mini games to include and value them in labor. On further extreme, who whole complex game could be considered as a composition of mini games too. Example cases: - Progressive casting mechanism given above. - Lockpicking mechanism in Elder Scrolls series. - Hacking in Eve Online. __Internal Learning Mechanism__ The mechanic requirements to solve puzzles or progression is aimed to be engraved in-game as much as possible. Player should not progress with grind with frozen state of mind, but immerse him/herself in the game content and try to solve a problem to make a progress. Example casees: - Trolls could be killed by using fire spells learned through a book (Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, 2011) - On crafting, player must adjust the necessary conditions to create best possible variations of weapon. This information could be retrieved from someone, or something from ingame. To avoid duplication of the solution outside of the game. Given sources are randomized every game. On example, to forge a good sword, player should set the temperature to correct level. The level is described as a color of something (for instance a peach) ingame by someone or some text. Player should get a peach to compare colors to see correct level adjustment. __Technology and Skill Trees__ Another factor to establish an immersive environment is to push player to think and theorycraft the problem space created in-game. To create this environment, I consider, technology, and skill trees are good method to create complexity and considering people to think over variances and new possibilities to play and interract with the game. However, I belive skills trees should not shadow the players control over the character. Fundamental success should still be binded to player. # Sub Systems __Time and Date__ A time system tracks day/night cycles and calendar to set events. To bind sense of time to certain events such as puzzles or social/unique events ingame that enhances to create more surrounding environment in parallelity with the idea of Gesamkunstwerk. __Inventory__ As a fundamental aspect of any role-playing game inventory system is aimed to include in Swapfold. To be able to progress on character, use of materials to create more powerful objects and increase environmental interaction. __Procedural Environment Generation__ Describing environment as modules and computationally bind this parts to describe seamlessly transitive places. The idea is to create relatively unique experience on each seed, as well as preventing the rote progression. - Example games using described system: Diablo series, Valheim, Don't Starve __Controlled Randomization__ - Map randomization: As a part of prodecural environment creation parts of the map is randomly customized - Puzzle randomization: To prevent same written guide to pass the game without playing it. The fold hints are given randomly to form a unique form for each puzzle instance. # References and Credits __Visual References__ 1. _Figure 1._ Basic level origamis selected for each chapter. Figure produced by the author. 2023. - Sampled From: _Twitter: The Art of Origami_. 2020. Accessed (10-Feb-2023) https://twitter.com/PaperFolding101/status/1249763477394161664 2. _Figure 2._ Fold and Power Word Asssociation on Skill Tree. Figure produced by the author. 2023. - Sampled From: _Ultima Online Spellbook_. n.d. Accessed (14-Feb-2023) https://runuo.theabyss.ru/images/uokr/sitecontent/skill/mysticism/mystbook.jpg - Sampled From: _Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Power Words_. 2011. Accessed (14-Feb-2023) https://i.ytimg.com/vi/xBqg1N1taEk/maxresdefault.jpg - Sampled From: _Elder Futhark_ n.d. Accessed (13-Feb-2023) https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Anglosaxonrunes.svg/1024px-Anglosaxonrunes.svg.png 3. _Figure 3._ Spell Effect Change In Relation To Cast Periods. Figure produced by the author. 2023. 4. _Figure 4._ Periods of Cast Bar. Figure produced by the author. 2023. 5. _Figure 5._ Puzzle Solving Steps Depiction. Figure produced by the author. 2023. __Used Sources__ 1. 3Blue1Brown. _Visualizing quaternions (4d numbers) with stereographic projection_. Youtube [Video File]. 2018. Accessed (12-Nov-2021) https://youtu.be/d4EgbgTm0Bgquartenions 2. "Camera Obscura". _In Wikipedia_. n.d. Accessed (25-Feb-2023) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Camera_obscura 3. "Chekhov's Gun". _In Wikipedia_. n.d. Accessed (25-Feb-2023) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chekhov%27s_gun 4. DevDungeon. _The Cookbook Method of Learning Programming Languages_. Youtube [Video File]. 2016. Accessed (13-Feb-2023) https://youtu.be/8vmUTz6it5A 5. Lucareilli, C.D.C., Carlo, J. _data.text:
This is my self citation notation. I required to create this documents since I could not find both reliable syntactically coherent and citation guide. - Citation might fully grammatical syntactic but might take long time to write and looks ugly. - Citation might be elegant but consist of a lot of exceptions and problematic cases. Aim of this study to mix a set elegant and systatic citation setup that includes vast range of sources without question marks. - referenc entry - footnote - in-text reference ## Citation Grammar Rules 1. Citation gives four **metadata information** about the source: - **Who**: Who has created the work? - **What**: What is the name of work? - **Where**: If it is published where? - **When**: When it is published or settled as frozen entity in history? - **How**: How do we reach it? Access link / doi etc. - The question why could be answered within the text or in footnotes but it is not a part of citation. - ex. Who. _What_. Where. When. How 2. One or information might be missing or not included. However, the order of the information is always the same and a citation should contain minimum 3 of the metadata information. - ex. Author. _Book_. Publisher. Date. 3. Each metadata information is separated and ended by . (dot) from each other except for **how**. - ex. Author. _Book_. Publisher. Date. 4. If the metadata is not conventional type: dissertation, book, article, newspaper. It should be indicated with square braces. - ex. [Video], [Podcast] 5. The source of the work is written italic. It might be a chapter of book, article in journal or a book itself. - ex. Author. _A Book_ . ... - ex. Author. "Article". In _Journal_. ... 7. Part of something relationships indicated through quotation marks. - ex. "Concept". In _Dictionary_. - ex. "Article" In _Journal_. 8. If the source name is in diffent language than article. The translation might be given in square braces after the name. - ex. Artikel [Article]. 9. Page numbers are cateorical exception handled as how. comes after date with : separation. **Example Book Citation:** Arendt, Hannah. _The Human Condition_. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. 1958. | Who | What | Where | When | How | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Arendt, Hannah . | _The Human Condition_ . | Chicago: University of Chicago Press . | 1958 . | - | # Parametrization | Name | Tag | Description | Example | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Constant | .. | Constant statement. That never changes. | Original work published at 1899. | Anything | [] | Indicates a selection between given options | \[ Master diss \| PhD diss ] | Discete | <> | Indicates a variable. | \ | Numeric | ## | Indicates a numeric value | #PageNumbers# ## Metadata Regulations - **Who** Who produced the work? Author, editor, producer etc. - **Occasions** - Single author - **Desciption** In bibliography reference last name is written first separated by comma (,) - **Formula** Last Name, First Name. - **Example** Newton, Isaac. - **Exception** If author has more than one names, only first name is written full rest is shortened by first letter. - ex. Popper, Karl R. - Two Author - **Desciption** In bibliography reference last name is written first separated by comma (,) First name or names written shortened by dot (.) at the end. - **Formula** Last Name 1, First Name First Letter 1. and Last Name 2, First Name First Letter 2. - **Example** Acemoƒülu, D. and Robinson, J. A. - Three or more author - **Desciption** Only first author name and constant abbreviation et al. (Latin abbreviation means "and others") - **Formula** Last Name of First Author et al. - **Example** Berg et al. - **Pseudonym** - **Desc** Sometimes authors uses nicknames for anonymity. In such cases pseudonym is written as it is with (pseudonym) constant. But if the pseudonym is well known the constant might be avoided. - **Formula** Pseudonym Name, (pseudonym). - **Example** Bulkhardt, Richard (pseudonym). - **Example** Le Corbusier. - **What** What is the name or title of the work? - Title of work - Part of something - **Where** Where the work is produced? - - **Formula** City: Publisher - When - Regular - Multiple publications in the same year - - How: How to find or accessed to the document - Links: Accessed (DD MMM YYYY) - Dois: ## Category Regulations # Articles - Articles are written text published in newspaper, journal, online platform or as book chapter. The most common type is appears as journal. | | Journal Article | |:-- |:-- | | **Formula** | \, \ . "\" . _\_ . \ . \ | **Example** | Shannon, Claude E. _data.text:
| Created       | Revision    | Version      |  
| :--           | :--         | :--          |
| 18-Apr-2023   | 25-Apr-2023 | 1.2          |

**Case Names**  
snake_case, PascalCase, camelCase, kebab-case, mixed_caseNaming 

## General Rules
1. Favor 3-4 char abbreviations if readable
- ex. vertex        : vrtx
- ex. fragment      : frag
- ex. color         : col
- ex. lahmacun      : lah

2. Use underscore(_) insread of whitespace( ) for spaces.
    1. if undescore is not available then the separator is dash(-)
    2. if both underscore and dash are not available than the convention is camelCase

## Classes, Structs
1. Always starts with a capital
2. Follows PascalCase
- ex. MyClass
- ex. ObjToDraw
- ex. ShaderCompileData

## Folders, Files
1. All small characters
    - ex. libs (folder name)
2. Well known names shorted to 3-4 characters: libraries: libs
3. File names could hold **prefix** or **abbreviated keywords** to sort related file together. 
    - **a / abst:** abstract data types    (structs / classes)
    - **d / data:** data                   (models, scenes, vertices, materials input in gerneral)
    - **m / map:** mapping                 (how to associate data / mappings ex. shader with file names)
    - **c / core:** core                   (main file)
    - **u / util:** utililities            (self written library functions, parsers / calculators etc.)
    - **x / test:** testing                (test files)

- ex. util_shaders.cpp (file name if not in util folder)
- ex. shaders.cpp (an utility code if )

## Variables
1. variables start with small character 
2. splits with underscore(_)
3. certain types marked with scale
    - **global    :** g_variable
    - **bools     :** b_isVariable
    - **constants :** k_variable
    - **pointers  :** p_variable
3. Prepositions are not separated
- ex. sizeof_students, distanceto_next_prime


## Functions
1. Starts with a verb
2. clearly describes what function does
3. Each function has only one task
4. Starts with a small character
5. Follows camelCase()
- ex. linkShaderProgram()
- ex. deleteCompiledShaders()

children.value: Passive voice is a grammatical construction in which the subject of a sentence is the recipient of the action, rather than the performer of the action. In other words, in a passive sentence, the thing being acted upon is the grammatical subject of the sentence, while the agent (the entity that is performing the action) is often relegated to a prepositional phrase or omitted altogether.

For example, in the active sentence "John ate the pizza," "John" is the subject and the performer of the action, while "pizza" is the object and the thing being acted upon. In the passive version of this sentence, "The pizza was eaten by John," "pizza" becomes the subject, while "John" is introduced via a prepositional phrase.

Passive voice is often used when the speaker wants to emphasize the thing being acted upon or when the performer of the action is unknown, irrelevant, or intentionally being obscured. However, passive voice can sometimes make sentences more wordy and harder to understand, so it's important to use it judiciously.
In German language the passiv structure has those properties.

Subjekt im A-Satz -> von + D im P-Satz

## Das Tempus und Passivsatzbildung Passive voice is a grammatical construction in which the subject of a sentence is the recipient of the action, rather than the performer of the action. In other words, in a passive sentence, the thing being acted upon is the grammatical subject of the sentence, while the agent (the entity that is performing the action) is often relegated to a prepositional phrase or omitted altogether. For example, in the active sentence "John ate the pizza," "John" is the subject and the performer of the action, while "pizza" is the object and the thing being acted upon. In the passive version of this sentence, "The pizza was eaten by John," "pizza" becomes the subject, while "John" is introduced via a prepositional phrase. Passive voice is often used when the speaker wants to emphasize the thing being acted upon or when the performer of the action is unknown, irrelevant, or intentionally being obscured. However, passive voice can sometimes make sentences more wordy and harder to understand, so it's important to use it judiciously. In German language the passiv structure has those properties. 1. Use of the subject is not obligatory in passive sentence. However, it could be done in this way: - Subjekt im A-Satz -> von + D im P-Satz 2. Accusative object in active sentence becomes subject in passive sentence. - Akk-Obj. im A-Satz -> Subjekt im P-Satz 3. In passiv sentence everytime we have always one more verb. - werden + Partizip II - sein + Partizip II + worden - werden + Partizip II + Inf. von werden | Zeit | Tempus | Aktiv Beispiel | Passiv Beispiel | | :---------------: | :-----------------: | :-------------------------------: | :---------------------------------: | | die Gegenwart | das Pr√§sens | Man liest das Buch. | Das Buch wird gelesen. | | die Vergangenheit | das Pr√§teritum | Man las das Buch. | Das Buch wurde gelesen. | | die Vergangenheit | das Perfekt | Man hat das Buch gelesen. | Das Buch ist gelesen worden. | | die Vergangenheit | das Plusquamperfekt | Man hatte das Buch gelesen. | Das Buch war gelesen worden. | | die Gelegenheit | das Futur I | Man wird das Buch lesen. | Das Buch wird gelesen werden. | | die Gelegenheit | das Futur II | Man wird das Buch gelesen haben. | Das Buch wird gelesen worden sein. | **Umformulierung** Ich fahre meine Mutter ins Krankenhaus. 1. Ich = Subjekt | meine Mutter = Akk. obj. 2. fahren (Pr√§sens) -> (ist) gefahren 3. Fahren + Akk -> hat gefahren - Meine Mutter wird (von mir) ins Krankenhaus gefahren. **Beispiele** - Katja Screibt einen Brief. (Pr√§s. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wird (von Katja) geschrieben. (Pr√§s. Passiv.) - Katja schrieb einen Brief (Pr√§t. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wurde (von Katja) geschrieben. (Pr√§t. Passiv.) - Katja hat einen Brief geschrieben. (Perf. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief ist (von Katja) geschrieben worden. (Perf. Passiv.) - Katja hatte einen Brief geschrieben. (Pqp. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief war geschrieben worden. (Pqp. Passiv.) - Katja wird einen Brief schrieben. (F1. Aktiv.) - Ein Brief wird geschrieben werden. (F1. Passiv.) - Katja wird einen Brief geschrieben haben. (F2. Aktiv.) (Disregard for now, usage is rarely) - Ein Brief von Katja geschrieben worden sein. (F2. Passiv.) ## Modale Saetze Modal sentences provide information about how (wie?) / by which (wodurch) / in which way (auf welche Art / Weise) on a topic. **Beispiel:** **Dadurch** achten seine Ern√§hrung und sich ausgewogen ern√§hren, kann mann fitter werden. **Through** paying attention to his diet and eating a balanced diet, man can become fitter. In this example Dadurch indicates the method, and statement answers the question **How** can one become fit? Modal sentences could be formed through three possibilities 1. Nebensatzkonnektor - indem | dadurch, dass - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokabeln, indem ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - wie lernst du Vokabeln? - Ich lerne Vokabeln dadurch, dass ich sie ganz oft wiederhole. - Man soll immer gesund essen. Man kann dadurch fitter Werden. - Ich habe ein Semester gesparrt, indem ich die Uni gewechselt habe. - Charles Lindbergh wurde ber√ºhmt, indem er 1927 √ºber den Atlantik geflogen ist. - Dadurch, dass sich die Erde um sich selbst dreht, kommen Tag und Nacht zustande. - Indem ich fr√ºh aufstehe, habe ich genug Zeit f√ºr Sport. (By getting up early, I have enough time for sports.) 2. Verbindungsadverb - dadurch / so - Dadurch konnte ich meine Ziele erreichen. (This way, I was able to achieve my goals.) - So bin ich schneller ans Ziel gekommen. (This way, I reached my destination faster.) 2. Pr√§positionen - durch + Akk (= Methode) Nominalisierung - mit + Dat. (= Instrument) - Durch intensives Training hat er seine Sprachkenntnisse verbessert. (Through intensive training, he improved his language skills.) - Mit meinem Fahrrad fahre ich jeden Tag zur Arbeit. (I ride my bike to work every day.) ## Final- und Adversativsatze # Finals√§tze Finalsatz describes a goal or intention. Der Finalsatz gibt den Zweck, die Absicht oder das Ziel der beschriebenen Handlung oder des Sachverhalts an. Man trennt den Finalsatz durch ein Komma vom √ºbergeordneten Satz ab. Finalsatz answers the question **wozu?** There is two common forms of creating final sentences. 1. **Infinitiv** : um .. zu .. 2. **Konnektor** : damit | | | |:--|:--| | **Handlung/Meinung/Status** | Wir brauchen einen Saugroboter. | **Zweck/Absicht** | Wir sparen Zeit. - **Nina:** Wozu brauchen wir einen Saugroboter? - **Sebastian:** Wir brauchen einen Saugroboter, **um** Zeit **zu** sparen. - **Sebastian:** Ich m√∂chte einen Saugroboter kaufen, damit wir Zeit sparen. **Beispiele:** - Ich lerne Deutsch, **damit** ich mich auf Reisen verst√§ndigen kann. - Er spart Geld, **um** sich sp√§ter ein Haus kaufen **zu** k√∂nnen. - Du dr√ºckst auf diesen Knopf, **um** die Maschine ein**zu**schalten. Der Finalsatz mit um ‚Ä¶ zu hat kein eigenes Subjekt. Deshalb ist diese Satzstruktur nur m√∂glich, wenn das Subjekt im √ºbergeordneten Satz und im Finalsatz gleich ist. The Finalsatz with um .. zu + (inf) structure only possible with the same subject. If the subject is changing then connector **damit** should be used. - Du machst kreisende Bewegungen, um jede Pore mit Chemie zu f√ºllen. - Du f√ºllst Teppichreiniger in die Maschine, damit ich den Teppich sauber machen kann. # Adversativs√§tze | Gegens√§tze Adversativsatz or Gegensatz indicates a opposite condition/situation to first sentence. Adversative Konjunktionen verwendet man, um eine Einschr√§nkung, einen Widerspruch oder einen Gegensatz auszudr√ºcken. Zwei Konjunktionen, die man oft benutzt, sind aber und doch. Some of the commonly used Adversativsatz connectors are: **aber, doch, jedoch** **Beispiele:** - Ich m√∂chte eine eigene Praxis er√∂ffnen, aber ich habe nicht genug Geld. - Ich m√∂chte eine eigene Praxis er√∂ffnen, doch ich habe nicht genug Geld. - Ich m√∂chte eine eigene Praxis er√∂ffnen, jedoch habe ich nicht genug Geld. Die Konjunktionen aber und doch stehen zwischen zwei Haupts√§tzen. In beiden Haupts√§tzen ver√§ndert sich die Reihenfolge der Satzteile nicht, wenn man die S√§tze mit aber und doch verbindet. Ich kann **jedoch** viel arbeiten. - Ich bin kein reicher Mann, kann **jedoch** viel arbeiten.

## Kasus: Akkusativ und Dativ # Accusative case **What is case** Case refers to the grammatical category of a noun, pronoun, or adjective that reflects its syntactic and semantic role in a sentence. There are four cases in German grammar. Table below is to represent rough functions of these cases in the sentence and all of them color coded. While the nominative case is part of former chapters. In here, akkusativ and dativ cases will be focused. | Case | Function | Examle | |:-- |:-- |:-- | | Nominativ | Subject of verb | Ich gebe. | Akkusativ | Direct object | Ich gebe das Grammatikbuch. | Dativ | Indirect object | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Grammatikbuch. | Genitiv | Possession indicative | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Grammatikbuch der deutschen Sprache. **How to identify accusative case?** There are four situations to identify accusative object in German. 1. Direct object: In most basic example, accusative case refers to the direct object in sentence. Or in other words what is being "verbed". | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gebe das Buch. | **Explanation** | In this example verb is "gebe" give what is given: the book
This condition could be identified by the questions in the sentence **what?** 2. Accusative prepositions: Some prepositions in German always require accusative case. Those prepositions are: _durch_, _f√ºr_, _gegen_, _ohne_, _um_ and _entlang_. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich fahre *gegen* die Wand. | **Translation** | I drive against the wall. | **Explanation** | The direct object in the accusative case, governed by the preposition "gegen." 3. Accusative personal pronouns: There are accusative version of pronouns that indicates the case in sentence. Those needs to be learned by heart. | Nominativ | Akkusativ | Dativ | :-- | :-- | :-- | | ich | mich | mir | du | dich | dir | er | ihn | ihm | sie | sie | ihr | es | es | ihm | wir | uns | uns | ihr | euch | euch | sie | sie | ihnen | Sie | Sie | Ihnen | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Er sieht mich. | **Translation** | He sees me. | **Explanation** | Mich is personal pronoun accusative version of nominative ich. 4. Indefinite pronouns: Indefinite pronouns like someone (jemand) or something (etwas) are always in accusative case. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich suche etwas. | **Translation** | I am looking for something. | **Explanation** | Something is indefinite pronoun always in accusative. **Grammatical changes of accusative case** Accusative object in German sentences changes the definite or indefinite article of the object. The only difference between nominativ and accusative case occurs on masculine articles. | | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Nominativ | der | die | das | die | | Akkusativ | den | die | das | die | # Dativ Case Dative case in german refers to indirect object in sentence. The dative object is something affected by the action occured in sentence. It could be the noun that receives something in accusative case. The question to be asked to sentence to dative case is "Was?(what)". **How to identify dative case?** 1. Indirect object: The Dative case is used for the indirect object of a sentence. To determine the indirect object, ask "to/for whom" or "to/for what" the verb is acting upon. The indirect object usually comes before the direct object in the sentence. | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gebe meinem Vater das Buch. | **Explanation** | In this example the object book is given to who?
This condition could be identified by the questions in the sentence **whom?** 2. Dative prepositions: Some prepositions always require the Dative case. These include "aus" (out of), "bei" (at), "mit" (with), "nach" (after), "seit" (since), "von" (from), "zu" (to), and "gegen√ºber" (opposite). | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Ich gehe *mit* meinem Freund ins Kino. | **Explanation** | "Meinem Freund" is the indirect object in the dative case, governed by the preposition "mit". 3. Indirect object pronouns: Pronouns that represent the indirect object in a sentence are in the Dative case. | Nominativ | Akkusativ | Dativ | :-- | :-- | :-- | | ich | mich | mir | du | dich | dir | er | ihn | ihm | sie | sie | ihr | es | es | ihm | wir | uns | uns | ihr | euch | euch | sie | sie | ihnen | Sie | Sie | Ihnen | | | | :---------: | :---------------------: | | **Example** | Sie schickt mir eine E-Mail. | **Explanation** | "Mir" ist dative form of "ich" and represents indirect object in the sentence. **Grammatical changes of dative case** Dative object in German sentences changes the definite or indefinite article of the object. | | Masculine | Feminine | Neuter | Plural | | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | Nominativ | der | die | das | die | | Akkusativ | den | die | das | die | | Dativ | dem | der | dem | den |
**Differences** todo: mir ist kalt todo: prepositions gorseli, akk ve dativ todo: whom? question is both akkusative and dative
## Satzstruktur: Hauptsatz und Nebensatz Word order and subordinate clauses: German language has a strict positioning rule about the verbs. Those are: - **Hauptsatz:** (main clauses) Sentences that stands alone as a whole. The verb stand always in second position. - A single sentence may contain two or more verbs. The positioning may vary dependent on case, however in most situations like **modals verbs** auxiliary verb comes to second position while main verb goes to the end of the sentence. - ex. **Modalverb:** Ich kann mir vorstellen. - ex. **Perfekt:** Ich habe gestern gearbeitet. - **Attention:** Second position does not mean second word. First position might belong to a clause. - ex. Deutsche Grammatikb√ºcher sind sehr teuer. - **Haupsatz Konnektoren:** There are three basic connectors in German language to bind Hauptsatz. Those are, **und (and)**, **oder (or)**, and **aber (or)**. Those connectors. In Grammatical sense, these connectors refers to a new sentence beginnings. Could be regarded as dot. - ex. Ich gehe ins Kino, und meine Freunde kommen mit. - ex. Entweder gehen wir ins Kino, oder wir bleiben zu Hause. - ex. Ich m√∂chte ins Kino gehen, aber ich habe kein Geld. - **Nebensatz:** (subordinate clauses) Usually gives additional information about the main sentence. Could indicate reason, result etc. Subordinate clauses are there to create more complex sentences. And binded the main sentence with a specific connector Could be skipped for now. Yet there it might be helpful to see an example. - ex. Ich trinke Tee, weil ich Halsschmerzen habe. ## Modalverben und Kontext In German, modal verbs are a type of auxiliary verb that express modalities such as ability, possibility, permission, necessity, and obligation. There are 6 modal verbs in German. Those are: | Modalverb | Trans | Example | | :--------- | :---------- | :-- | | **k√∂nnen** | to be able to / can | ich kann schwimmen. | **m√ºssen** | must / have to | er muss seine Aufgaben erledigen. | **sollen** | should / should be supposed to | wir sollten nach Reykjavik gehen. | **d√ºrfen** | may / be allowed to | Sie d√ºrfen hier nicht rauchen. | **wollen** | want to | Ihr wolltet zu uns kommen. | **m√∂chten** | would like to | Sie will Tennis spielen. In order to use modalverbs correctly in Grammar. One needs to be aware of couple of things. 1. Verb position structure: In most basic German sentence 2. Declination of the modal verb according to subject. ## Prapositionen I: Ortangaben | Am, Im, Um # Ortsangaben In German, the preposition use with directions are dependent on two factors. Those are: 1. The question: Woher? (from where), Wo? (where). and Wohin? (to where) 2. Type of Place: enclosed space, city/country, people etc. | | Woher? ?->i (Dativ) | Wo? x (Dat) | Wohin? i->? (Akk) | | :--------- | :---------- | :-- | :-- | | **Stadt/Land** | aus | in | nach | **Menschen** | von | bei | zu | **Enclosed Space** | aus / von | in | zu / in | **Haus** | von zu | zu | nach - Examples - Stadt/ Land - Woher? Ich komme **aus** der T√ºrkei. - Wo? Jetzt bin ich **in** Berlin. - Wohin? Ich fahre **nach** Kassel. - Menschen - Woher? Ich komme **aus** Jen. - Wo? Ich bin **bei** Kenny. - Wohin? Ich fahre **zu** Fabian. - Eingeschlossener Raum (Enclosed Space / Space with limits) - Woher? Ich komme **von** der Uni. - Wo? Ich esse **in** der Mensa. - Wohin? Ich gehe zum Laufen **in** den Park. - Haus - Woher? Ich komme von zu Hause. - Wo? Ich bin zu Hause. - Wohin? Er ist auf dem Weg nach Hause. # Um, Im, Am - To indicate dadys of the week we use **am**: - am Montag, am Dienstag, am Vormittag, am Nachmittag, am Morgen - For seasons we use: **im**: - im Fr√ºhling, im Sommer, im Winter, im Herbst - To talk about a time in precision we use **um**: - um 19 Uhr - um 12 Uhr - um 15 Uhr 30 - um Mitternacht - Verb conjugation - an + dem = **am** - in + dem = **im** ## Vergangenheit I: Perfekt One of the fundamental aspects language is speaking about the past. The most basic grammatik time form (das Tempus) of past (die Vergangenheit) is **Perfekt**. In order to be able to create sentences in Perfekt. One needs to have various basic knowledge. 1. **Understanding of verb positioning** in German sentences. Since perfekt requires two verbs in one sentence. 2. **Partizip II** A special type of verb conjugation that is used in perfect and passiv sentences. | Examples | Pr√§sens | Perfekt | | :-- | :-- | :-- | | **sein regular** | Ich fahre nach Berlin. | Ich bin nach Berlin gefahren. | **sein irregular** | Ich gehe nach Hause. | Ich bin nach Hause gegangen. | **haben regular** | Ich lese das Buch. | Ich habe das Buch gelesen. | **haben irregular** | Ich esse zu viel. | Ich habe zu viel gegessen. Perfect sentences in German language uses passing conjugation of auxiliary verb (sein or haben). Which form is going to be used is dependent on the verb. 90% of the words uses "haben" while relocation indicating verbs such as gehen, fahren, laufen uses "sein". There are also some exceptions. Second part is the Partizip II version of the main verb. In Partizip II there are regular and irregular versions. Often needs to be learned by heart. **Conjugating Partizip II** Partizip II is also known as the past partipciple formed by adding prefix "ge-", and suffix "-t" or "-et" to the verb stem. It used in various ways. | Infinitiv | Stamm | Partizip II | Regular?| | :-- | :-- | :-- | :-- | | machen | mach | **ge**mach**t** | ja | spielen | spiel | **ge**spiel**t** | ja | lernen | lern | **ge**lern**t** | ja | sein | sei | gewesen | nein | haben | hab | gehabt | nein - **To form the Perfekt tense** - ex. Gestern habe ich eine E-Mail **geschrieben.** - To form the passive voice - Das Haus wurde **gebaut.** - A an adjective - ex. Ein **gekochtes** Ei # Beispiele im Perfekt 1. Ich lerne Deutsch - Ich habe Deutsch gelernt. (regular) 2. Er trinkt Kaffee. - Er hat Kaffee getrunken. (irregular) 3. Wir sprechen jeden Tag Deutsch. - Wir haben jeden Tag Deutsch gesprochen. (irregular) 4. Sie arbeitet in einer Firma. - Sie hat in einer Frima gearbeitet. (regular) 5. Ich esse gerne Pizza. - Ich habe gerne Pizza gegessen. (irregular) 6. Er liest ein Buch. - Er hat ein Buch gelesen. (irregular) 7. Wir fahren Morgen in den Urlaub. - Wir sind in den Urlaub gefahren. (Morgen passt hier kontextuell nicht.) (irregular) 8. It is often used in newspapers. **direkte Rede** Fabian sagt: "*Ich* gehe jetzt nach Hause." (I am going home now.) **indirekte Rede** Er sagte, *er* **gehe** jetzt nach Hause. ## Partizip I als Adjektiv Partizip I (also known as "present participle" or "gerund") in German is a non-finite verb form that ends in "-end", "-ierend", or "-end" depending on the verb. It is formed by adding the suffix "-end" or "-ierend" to the verb stem, and can function as an adjective, a noun or a verb. As an adjective, Partizip I describes an **ongoing action**, state or condition. It can be used to describe a person, an object or a situation. As partizip I converts verb to an adjektiv it is also followed by adjective declination: lauf**end**e Nase (running nose) arbeit**ende**r Mensch (working person) schwing**end**e H√§ngematte (swinging hammock)
